reasoning: The query focuses on the potential of technology to address youth unemployment in Sub-Saharan Africa. The current results acknowledge this potential but lack specific examples and in-depth analysis of relevant technologies and their successful implementation in the region. Therefore, the query needs to be expanded to explore specific technologies, relevant skills, and successful initiatives in Sub-Saharan Africa. The expansion should also consider the challenges and opportunities related to technology adoption and implementation in this context.
query_goals: Identify specific technologies with the potential to create employment opportunities for youth in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Explore case studies of successful technology-driven employment initiatives for youth in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Investigate the skills and training required for youth to participate in technology-related jobs in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Analyze the challenges and opportunities of technology adoption and implementation for youth employment in Sub-Saharan Africa.
Examine policies and programs that promote technology-driven youth employment in Sub-Saharan Africa.
nearest_neighbors: Digital skills training programs in Africa
Mobile technology and entrepreneurship for youth in Africa
E-commerce platforms empowering youth in Sub-Saharan Africa
Renewable energy jobs for youth in Africa
Agricultural technology and youth employment in Africa
Impact of internet access on youth employment in Africa
Government initiatives promoting technology-based youth employment in Africa
Fintech opportunities for youth in Africa
Remote work and online freelancing for youth in Africa
augmented_query: "Technology AND (job creation OR employment opportunities) AND youth AND Sub-Saharan Africa AND (digital skills OR mobile technology OR e-commerce OR renewable energy OR agricultural technology OR fintech) AND (training programs OR entrepreneurship OR remote work OR government initiatives) AND (unemployment OR underemployment)"
query: Technology will lead job growth for youths.  The rate of unemployment in Sub-Saharan Africa remains above the global average, at 7.55% in 2011, with 77% of the population in vulnerable employment [1] . Economic growth has not been inclusive and jobs are scarce. In particular, rates of youth unemployment, and underemployment, remain a concern [2] . On average, the underutilisation of youths in the labour market across Sub-Saharan Africa stood at 67% in 2012 (Work4Youth, 2013). Therefore 67% of youths are either unemployed, inactive, or in irregular employment. The rate of unemployment varies geographically and across gender [3] .  There remains a high percentage of youths within informal employment. Technology can introduce a new dynamic within the job market and access to safer employment.  Secure, high quality jobs, and more jobs, are essential for youths. Access to technology is the only way to meet such demands. Technology will enable youths to create new employment opportunities and markets; but also employment through managing, and selling, the technology available.  [1] ILO, 2013.  [2] Definitions: Unemployment is defined as the amount of people who are out of work despite being available, and seeking, work. Underemployment defines a situation whereby the productive capacity of an employed person is underutilised. Informal employment defines individuals working in waged and/or self employment informally (see further readings).  [3] Work4Youth (2013) show, on average, Madagascar has the lowest rate of unemployment (2.2%) while Tanzania has the highest (42%); and the average rate of female unemployment stands higher at 25.3%, in contrast to men (20.2%).
